ARTICLE.TITLE: Meghan Markle heartbreak: Key reason royal 'has it harder than Diana did'
ARTICLE.TEXT:
FREE now and never miss the top Royal stories again. SUBSCRIBE Invalid email Sign up fornow and never miss the top Royal stories again. We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see our Privacy Notice for details of your data protection rights.

Social media means that anyone in the public eye can face criticism ‒ just or otherwise ‒ from any member of the public at any time. Sometimes people are critical, but reasonable, but at other times comments can be overwhelmingly hateful. The Duchess of Sussex has faced vile trolling on social media over the last few years, which Prince Harry claimed displayed “outright sexism and racism”.

Trending

She has even been accused of faking her pregnancy, among other bizarre conspiracies, and been issued threats of violence. Harry has spoken about how social media comments can negatively impact mental health and Meghan admitted it was a “struggle”. A Buckingham Palace statement last year said they encouraged social media users engaging with their online channels to show “courtesy, kindness and respect”. The rules listed on the Royal Family website say comments should not be “defamatory, deceive others, be obscene, offensive, threatening, abusive, hateful, inflammatory or promote sexually explicit material, violence or discrimination”. READ MORE: Meghan Markle rejected Palace advice that was ‘only safe course'

Meghan Markle faces issues caused by social media that Princess Diana did not

Kate Middleton has also faced horrible comments from trolls

Kensington Palace officials said they spend several hours a week trying to moderate and delete abusive comments about Meghan, but also about Kate Middleton. A source told The Sun: “It was pretty vile for a while. “There are automated tools which can help to police the very inappropriate comments getting through and also manual moderation ‒ but there are often thousands of comments. “It only takes a couple of people to stir up a really nasty conversation with people being very aggressive.”

Prince Harry has spoken about how comments on social media can affect people's mental health

Princess Anne said it is "more difficult" for young royals now due to social media

Anne said: “The pressure that is applied to the younger members of the family is always worse because that’s what the media is interested in, and that’s hard sometimes to deal with. “But there was no social media in my day, so it probably has made it more difficult.” Over the past few months, Meghan and Harry have supported efforts to hold social media companies to account. They supported a boycott of Facebook in July called Stop Hate For Profit, whereby companies were asked not to advertise on Facebook during that month, depriving the giant of a large amount of income.

This was a bid to encourage Facebook to start taking responsibility for the hate and fake news that spreads on its site. Then, last week, Harry wrote an opinion article on The Fast Company, in which he claimed there is a “crisis of health, hate and truth online”. He urged companies to take a stand to make a more compassionate social media space. Not only do young royals have to contend with social media abuse, they also have to cope with the ever-presence of smartphones.

METADATA.description: MEGHAN MARKLE arguably had a tougher time after marrying a prince than Princess Diana did, due to the fact social media was not around in Diana's day.
